text: going to Ellesmere on and seeing the
wolves is like going back to the Garden
of Eden to a time when we're not in
conflict with wolves and there's very
few places in the world you can do that
and in my long career as a filmmaker as
a biologist I've never seen anything
like it and in a way it for me it was
life-changing
to me wolves represent the wilderness
but they're also burned into our
imagination both in fear and in
fascination wolves are also something
that were drawn to their mysterious the
reason we went to Ellesmere Island is
because the Wolves there are naive to
humans so we knew that there was the
possibility of making contact with
wolves that had never seen people and
the reason that we wanted to do that was
to try and get a deeper insight into the
true nature of wolves I've worked in the
Arctic before and even in the High
Arctic
but Ellesmere Island is completely
different it's it's the size of Britain
and it's a polar desert but it only gets
about four centimeters of precipitation
every year and it's this incredibly
stark environment
it's an incredible remote oasis of
hierarch wildlife that not many people
have seen
wolves everywhere else in the planet run
away when they see humans
that's just what wolves do and they do
that because they're persecuted but here
and Ellesmere Island they're not
persecuted but what was really shocking
for me is that when the helicopter was
landing the symbols ran up ran towards
it I've been all around the world
filming predators and I've never seen
wild animals running up to the
helicopter while the blades were
spinning so we knew we're in for
something different
the Wolf Den we found was in a
remarkable location it was in a valley
overlooking the ocean
icebergs blue sky and snow-capped
mountains in a distance and we set up a
camp at a respectful distance and then
over a period of days started working on
ourselves closer to the Wolves to get
them used to our presence
we wanted to get a view inside the mouth
of the den but we didn't want to push
our lock and get too close to earth
and so we deployed this cool bit of
technology called a rock crawler what it
allowed us to do is carry remote cameras
right up to the mouth of the Dead
and it was funny about it as the Wolves
never seen anything like it they didn't
know what to make of it we managed to
tilt the camera and point it in to the
mouths of the dead were pleasantly
surprised when three young pups came to
investigate and those are some of the
cutest shots warden Buchanan's role was
hugely important because he's both the
wildlife cameraman and somebody who has
great sensitivity around animals and I
think those two qualities were and
skills were important in getting access
to the wolf family as you can see from
these extraordinary photos the proximity
to the Wolves the closeness the wolves
is mind-boggling I thought we would get
close but never that close to be and to
be there right beside them to be touched
by them to be sniffed by them it's
incredible
and we see an animal like a wolf in and
were filled with fear we can't help that
and a lot of what we were trying to do
and what Gordon was trying to do was
work through that fear to see what was
real versus what was a projection from
our mind and and what we found was as we
work through our layers of our anxiety
being around the wolves is that the
Mendes no harm
to gain the trust of a wolf family and
to be that close to the man to be able
to walk with him and be able to live
amongst them is something that I don't
believe has happened for 10,000 years
and it's because of the sensitivity of
Gordon and the scientists that were able
to do that in and show the wider world
what wolves really like
